awd_titl_txt: Analysis, Simulation, and Applications of Stochastic Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Stochastic systems are systems in which random disturbances play a significant role. Stemming from emerging and existing applications in networked systems, wireless communications, signal processing, economics, and ecology, this project encompasses the study of dynamically evolving stochastic systems with uncertainties, switching among different configurations, and complex structures. The networked systems of interest include financial, communication, social, biological, and ecological networks. The work will be devoted to learning the intrinsic properties of stochastic network systems, developing mathematical models and novel mathematical methods for analyzing such systems, and designing efficient computational schemes for optimization and  control of such systems to meet desired goals. The results of the research will be useful for applications to economics, nonlinear system identification and estimation, un-manned vehicles and other multi-agent systems, biodiversity in ecological systems, and social networks. This projects will involve undergraduate and graduate students and will integrate the research with teaching and student training. This work will contribute jointly to the further development of mathematical theory, computational methods and applications, and the improvement of mathematics education. 

Motivated by a wide variety of applications, this project will study the following research topics. (1)Stochastic models with random switching will be developed and analyzed. Novel features of the systems include (i) past-dependent switching having a countable state space, and (ii) switching jump diffusions with non-local operators, finite switching set, and sigma finite jump measures. Criteria for recurrence, positive recurrence, and ergodicity will be obtained. (2) Kolmogorov-type systems under white noise perturbations, where the diffusions are degenerate, will be investigated. Applications to control dependent environmental protection zones, infectious disease and ecology will be studied. (3) New algorithms for switching diffusions and stochastic approximation will be developed and their rates of convergence will be studied. (i) For Milstein-type algorithms for solutions of switching diffusions, it will be shown that the algorithms preserve order 1 convergence rates as their diffusion counterpart. (ii) Motivated by applications to multi-agent systems, consensus, and swarming, the novelties of the stochastic approximation algorithms include the inclusion of state-dependent switching, state-dependent observation noise, and general time-dependent nonlinear functions. (4) Precise error estimates for identification of Hammerstein nonlinear systems with quantized observations will be obtained. It will be proved that the estimates escape from a small neighborhood of the true parameter with a probability that is exponentially small. (5) Accurate error bounds for approximation schemes of duplication-deletion random networks in the sense of strong approximation will be obtained. This will have impact on the study of random dynamic graphs and applications to social networks. Extensive numerical experiments and simulations will be performed to complement the analysis and algorithm design. The projects will involve the participation of undergraduate and graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
Stochastic systems are such systems in which noise disturbances play a significant role not avoidable. Stochastic differential equations are differential equations that involve randomness not predictable. Motivated by applications in social networks, biological systems, ecological systems, financial systems, communication networks, among other, this project encompassed the study of dynamically evolving stochastic systems with uncertainties, random switching, and complex structures. Our work included analyzing complex stochastic systems, learning important features of nonlinear systems perturbed by random noise, designing algorithms for solutions of stochastic equations and switching stochastic differential equations, and constructing numerical procedures with complex and time-varying features, as well as carrying out case studies of corresponding applications. The research topics are all motivated by or abstracted from real applications. The research work included mathematical modeling, stochastic analysis, algorithms design, numerical experiments, and simulations. The next a few paragraphs illustrate several specific accomplishments in simple terms.

(1) We addressed a long-standing question of fundamental importance for mathematical aspect of biology and ecology, namely, what are the minimal conditions for long-term persistence and extinction of a population?  The phenomena go far beyond biological and ecological systems, and are suitable for a large class of nonlinear systems. In contrast to the existing works, our work substantially advanced our understanding for the underlying systems allowing delay and past dependence, to provide essential utility to a wider range of applications.

(2)  Focusing on stochastic differential equations with infinite delay, we examined certain intrinsic properties such as the coefficients not satisfying classical conditions. We established the existence and uniqueness of solutions and certain important properties such as memoryless property.

(3) For complex systems, we separate the variables in accordance with the fast-varying and slowly-changing features of different components. This enabled us to reduce the complexity by deriving certain limit (or reduced) systems. The rationale is that one can examine the much simpler reduced systems to learn the property and design the optimal strategy of the original complex systems.

(4) Examining a class of cancer models (stochastic Kuznetsov-Taylor tumor-immune models), our mathematical study yields sharp results. The results will be useful to the cancer treatment from the angle of mathematics.

(5) With the motivation of the needs in actuarial science and risk management, our work developed a deep learning approach. This leads to optimal reinsurance, investment, and dividend strategies for an insurance company.

(6) Working on infectious diseases models, one of our works investigated an epidemic model with the so-called incidence rate being sufficiently general to cover most existing incidence rate models in the literature.

(7) We investigated the inherent interaction between control and communication systems by designing a class of approximation/optimization numerical algorithms. The algorithms accommodate random network topology switching processes, nonlinear dynamics, additive and non-additive noises, and other uncertainties in a unified framework.

(8) We designed new algorithms for stochastic differential equations with truncation devices. We also ascertained the optimal convergence rates for a class of efficient algorithms for stochastic differential equations with random switching.

In addition to the aforementioned tasks, we developed new stochastic partial differential equation models for ecology applications, treated applications to wastewater treatment mathematically through a class of chemostat models, developed mathematical models and analysis of general stochastic differential equations with random jump and random switching, and studied mathematical formulation of energy systems, etc. All these studies contribute to the advancement of applied probability and stochastic theory with broad impact to a wider range of applications.
